text: there's nothing along those beaches 25
kilometres of undeveloped beach this is
Cornelia Dean for the New York Times and
this pristine coastline is in meeches on
the eastern shore of the Dominican
Republic but unfortunately idyllic
scenery is not the whole story here in
contrast to developed areas of the
country here the roads are bad the
electricity's erratic the waters dirty
and many people live in poverty meeches
is waiting for its future but what kind
of future will it be an unusual
collaboration of government leaders
local residents and Columbia University
researchers is working to shape it I
recently traveled to me chess with
Donald Melnick who directs the Columbia
University Center for environment
economy and society the people of
meeches came to the government for
specific reason down the road about 100
kilometers about 60 miles down the road
was an enormous hotel complex and what
they were afraid of as it was moving
down the coast toward them what they are
afraid of is the kind of development
that prevails in much of the Caribbean
high impact all-inclusive foreign-owned
resorts what they hope for instead is
low-key nature-based environmentally
sustainable tourism facilities they will
own and operate themselves they took
this hope to President leonel fernandez
and he recruited dr. Melnick steam to
work with them so they said something
that I found very poignant for the first
time I met with them they said you know
we are poor which is true but me Chase
is ours what we're afraid of is that we
will still be poor and me Chase will no
longer be ours meeches sits in a basin
ring by lush mountains its town square
is ripe for cafes and shops offshore
dolphins swim but the people here have
struggled for centuries to make a living
years of deforestation and farming have
damaged the meeches watershed and
therefore the beach
the water these boys are swimming in is
filthy trash litters the shore all of
the rain that hits on the northern
slopes of this range will obviously
drain downhill and draining downhill is
running north toward the ocean clean
water is the team's initial focus
everything from controlling agricultural
runoff to protecting offshore reefs from
pollution that threatens fish stocks on
this street sanitation was limited to
chamber pots people emptied into the sea
now thanks to the project there are
latrines eventually development here may
look like low-impact resorts in st. John
in the Virgin Islands where visitors
stay in platform tents or it may be a
day trip destination for tourists at
resorts down the coast if people here
hold out against big time developers a
few years ago some residents had begun
to sell out in the downtown area of me
chase you'll see some houses being
redone going from one floor to two
floors very nicely painted and there
might be an SUV out front and those are
people who got money for their land but
for now the absence of good road access
to michas and the weakened global
economy have given the project some time
for the new york times this is Cornelia
Dean
